questions.text: A surgeon takes the following 2 images of a patient's arm 6 weeks apart. Which of the following mediators promote the process shown below?
questions.solution:
The image shows wound healing. TGF-β (transforming growth factor-β) is responsible for wound healing.

TGF-β is produced by B and T cells and it inhibits their proliferation. It acts as a growth factor for fibroblasts and promotes wound healing. It stimulates the production of collagen, fibronectin and proteoglycans. It also promotes class switching of B cells to IgA. IL-10 is also involved in wound healing and suppression of inflammation. 

Option B: IFN-α inhibits viral replication, activates NK cells, and regulates the activity of macrophages and T cells.

Option C: TNF-α is involved in tumour cytotoxicity, phagocytic cell activation, and antiviral and antiparasitic effects. It is an acute phase protein. 

Option D: IFN-β has antiviral activity. 

Related Pearl: Cytokines

Interleukins Main sources
IL-1 (α and β) Macrophages and other cell types
IL-2 T cells
IL-3 T cells
IL-4 TH cells
IL-5 TH cells
IL-6 TH, macrophages, fibroblasts
IL-8 Macrophages, others
IL-10 T, B cells, macrophages

Pro-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-1: induces inﬂammation, fever, and sepsis, activates TNF-α; proliferation and differentiation of T, B, and other cells; bone marrow cell proliferation
  • IL-2: promote growth and differentiation of T and B cells; cytotoxicity of T and NK cells; secretion of other lymphokines
  • IL-6: promote B cell stimulation & differentiation; mediator of acute phase reactions; IgG production
  • IL-8: attracts and activates neutrophils in inflammatory regions; neutrophil chemotaxis
  • IFN-α: antiviral, immunoregulatory (enhance MHC class I, NK-cell activity), antiproliferative
  • TNF-α: activate macrophages and cytotoxic cells, induce cachexia, acute phase proteins, cytokines such as IL-1 and IL-6

Anti-inflammatory cytokines: 

  • IL-4: proliferation of B and cytotoxic cells; increases IgG1 and IgE production; enhances MHC-class II receptor
  • IL-10: inhibits IFN-γ and IL-12 production; inhibits IFN production and mononuclear cell functions
  • IL-13

Acute inflammation and sepsis: 

  • TNF-α
  • IL-1

Special Cytokines: 

  1. IFN-γ: 
    • Granuloma formation
    • Antiviral
    • Immunoregulatory (enhances MHC classes I and II and macrophage activation)
    • Antiproliferative
  2. TGF-β: 
    • Fibrosis 
    • Activate macrophages
  3. VEGF:
    • promotes angiogenesis

questions.text: What type of motility is shown by Treponema pallidum?
questions.solution:
Treponema pallidum show corkscrew motility, i.e movement by rotation around the long axis.

The characteristic feature of spirochetes is the presence of endoflagella, situated between the outer membrane and cell wall, that facilitates this movement. 

Related Pearl: Types of motility of microorganisms

Motility Microorganism
Darting/vibratory motility  Vibrio,Campylobacter
Swarming motility Cl. septicum, B.cereus, Proteus, some Vibrio sp
Tumbling motility  Listeria monocytogenes
Stately motility Clostridia
Spinning motility Fusobacterium gyrans
Cork-screw motility  Treponema pallidum
Falling leaf motility Giardia
Twitching motility Eikenella corrodens
Differential motility (Motility varies at different temperatures) Yersinia enterocolitica & Listeria monocytogenes
Jerky motility  Trichomonas vaginalis
Gliding motility Mycoplasma, Entamoeba
Lashing motility  Saprophytic spirochetes

questions.text: The egg shown below belongs to:
questions.solution:
The given egg belongs to whipworm or Trichuris trichiura.

The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:

  • Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. The plugs are colorless.
  • They float in the saturated salt solution.
  • It has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown.

Whipworms live in the large intestine and whipworm eggs are passed in the feces of infected persons. The eggs develop in the soil in 3-4 weeks and become infective to man. When these embryonated eggs containing infective larvae contaminate food or water, they can cause infections in humans. 

 

Related Pearl: Parasites with bile-stained eggs

The following are the parasites with bile-stained eggs. (mnemonic: FaT CAT)

  • Fasciola hepatica (sheep liver fluke)
  • Fasciolopsis buski (giant intestinal fluke)
  • Trichuris trichiura (whipworm)
  • Clonorchis sinensis (chinese liver fluke, oriental liver fluke)
  • Ascaris lumbricoides (round worm)
  • Taenia solium (pork tapeworm)
  • Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm)

Related Pearl: Helminth eggs that float in saturated salt solution

The following are the helminths whose eggs float in a saturated salt solution. (mnemonic: THE FAN)

  • Trichuris trichiura
  • Hymenolepis nana
  • Enterobius vermicularis
  • Fertilized eggs of Ascaris lumbricoides
  • Ancylostoma duodenale
  • Necator americanus.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the reticulate body of Chlamydia?
questions.solution:
The reticulate body of chlamydia is a growing and replicative form.

Chlamydia is a gram-negative coccobacillus that has the following features-

  • They are obligate intracellular organisms as they lack the enzymes for ATP synthesis, and are hence dependent entirely on the host cell. 
  • They can exist in two states.
    • The extracellular infective form is called the elementary body.
    • The intracellular non-infective form is called the reticulate body. These reticulate bodies are found inside a membrane-bound compartment called the "inclusion body" which can be visualized within infected epithelial cells by iodine or Giemsa stain. The cell of the reticulate body is fragile and pliable, leading to pleomorphism.
  • They are small bacteria about 0.2-0.3 microns in size and are hence filtrable through the pore size of standard bacterial filters.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with AIDS presents to the local clinic complaining of fever, nausea, vomiting and confusion. A lumbar puncture is performed and the microscopic appearance of India ink-stained CSF specimen is given below. Which of the following drugs is most beneficial in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the India ink preparation demonstrating clear halos is suggestive of cryptococcal meningitis caused by Cryptococcus neoformans. Flucytosine and amphotericin B are used in the treatment of this condition.

C. neoformans spreads from inhalation of the yeast cells in pigeon feces, causing infection in HIV/AIDS and other immunosuppressive conditions. It causes influenza-like respiratory infection in immunocompetent persons. In immunocompromised individuals, it disseminates to CNS, causing cryptococcal meningoencephalitis, and patients may complain of headaches, neck stiffness, and disorientation, as in this case. Other common sites of dissemination include the skin, adrenals, bone, eye, and prostate gland.

Diagnosis is made by demonstration of yeast cells or cryptococcal antigen in CSF. India ink stain is used to demonstrate capsulated budding yeast cells in CSF as they have a distinctive appearance because their capsules exclude ink particles. Rapid detection of cryptococcal antigen in CSF and blood can also be done. Colonies develop within a few days on most media at room temperature or 37°C. Media with cycloheximide should be avoided as it inhibits Cryptococcus.

Combination therapy of amphotericin B and flucytosine has been considered the standard treatment for cryptococcal meningitis.

Other options: 

Ketoconazole is usually used for chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis.

Nystatin is also used for mucocutaneous forms of candidiasis.

Miconazole is used for topical fungal infections like oral thrush, and vaginitis.

questions.text:
A young man comes with complaints of intermittent bloody diarrhea for 3 weeks after consuming street food during his travel. He is febrile and has RUQ tenderness. Which of the following is the infective form of the likely protozoan causing this disease?

RUQ - Right upper quadrant
questions.solution:
This patient has had bloody diarrhea for 3 weeks after eating street food, making a parasite the likely cause of his dysentery. His diarrhea combined with RUQ tenderness indicating a hepatic abscess makes Entamoeba histolytica the causative organism in this case.  The mature quadrinucleate cyst is the infective form of Entamoeba histolytica causing amoebic dysentery. It is passed in feces and can remain viable under moist conditions for about 10 days.

The following are the characteristic features of various life stages of Entamoeba histolytica:

The trophozoite is found only in tissues. Its cytoplasm has a ground-glass appearance. The nucleus has a central karyosome with radiating fibrils called linin network giving a cartwheel appearance. Pseudopodia are present which exhibit gliding motility.

The image below shows the trophozoite form.

The precystic stage has a large glycogen vacuole and 2 chromatid bars. It secretes a refractile cyst wall to become a cyst. The cystic stage has a mature cyst with 4 nuclei and no glycogen mass. Chromatid bars disappear.

The below image shows cystic form.

Related Pearl: Infective form and diagnostic forms of various protozoa

Parasite Infective form Diagnostic form
Entamoeba histolytica Mature quadrinucleate cyst Trophozoites, quadrinucleate cyst
Giardia lamblia Quadrinucleate cyst Trophozoites, cyst
Trichomonas vaginalis Trophozoites Trophozoites
Naegleria fowleri Trophozoite Trophozoite in CSF
Acanthamoeba Trophozoites and cysts Trophozoite in CSF
Leishmania donovani Promastigote amastigotes in macrophage
Trypanosoma cruzi Metacyclic Trypomastigote Trypomastigote
Trypanosoma brucei Metacyclic Trypomastigote Trypomastigote
Balantidium coli Cysts Cysts
Plasmodium spp. Sporozoites Schizont, immature trophozoite, mature trophozoite, gametocyte
Babesia spp. Sporozoites Maltese cross form
Toxoplasma gondii All 3 morphological forms - oocyst, tachyzoite, bradyzoite Tachyzoites, tissue cysts
Cryptosporidium parvum Sporulated oocyst Sporulated oocyst
Cyclospora cayetanensis Sporulated oocyst unsporulated oocyst
Isospora belli Sporulated oocyst unsporulated oocyst

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, arthralgia, and pain behind the eyes for 3 days. On examination, she has the following rash. Lab reports show thrombocytopenia and leucopenia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the symptoms and the rash suggests dengue fever.

It presents with sudden-onset fever, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, arthralgia, and a rash. The rash in dengue appears as white islands on a red sea due to erythema with petechiae. The alternative name for dengue, breakbone fever, comes from the associated muscle and joint pains.

Suspected cases of dengue are confirmed by the presence of NS1 antigen or IgM antibodies.

The treatment of dengue is supportive with hydration taking top priority. Severe cases where there is symptomatic thrombocytopenia or a platelet count of <10000-20000 cells/cumm require platelet transfusions.

questions.text: A 9 year old boy presents with burning sensation on passing urine. He mentions that the urine appears bright red. Urine analysis shows hematuria but no bacteria. Which of the following is the causative organism
questions.solution:
Dysuria and hematuria in a child in the absence of bacteria in the urine suggest a diagnosis of hemorrhagic cystitis. It is commonly caused by adenovirus.

Adenoviruses are non-enveloped dsDNA viruses. They cause infections of the respiratory tract, eye, bladder and intestine. The following table shows various syndromes caused by adenoviruses and associated serotypes:

Syndrome Adenovirus serotypes
Respiratory disease in children 1, 2, 5, 6
Sore throat, febrile cold, pneumonia 3, 4, 7, 14, 21
ARD in military recruits 4, 7, 21
Follicular (swimming pool) conjunctivitis/ Pharyngoconjunctival fever 3, 7
Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis (shipyard eye) 8, 19, 37
Diarrhea 40, 41
Acute hemorrhagic cystitis 11, 21

questions.text: A 19-year-old boy presented with a single painless papule on his penis with no enlarged lymph nodes. A smear was made from the lesion and stained with Wright- Giemsa stain which showed the finding as shown in the following picture. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the image showing Donovan bodies in Wright/Giemsa-stained impression smears indicate a diagnosis of donovanosis caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. They appear as rounded coccobacilli within cystic spaces in large mononuclear cells (called Pund cells).

Klebsiella granulomatis shows bipolar condensation of chromatin giving a safety pin appearance.

Bipolar staining (safety pin appearance) is shown by:

  • H. ducreyi
  • Vibrio parahaemolyticus
  • Klebsiella granulomatis
  • Yersinia pestis
  • Burkholderia pseudomallei
  • Burkholderia mallei

Related Pearl: Comparison of Genital Ulcers

  Genital herpes  Syphilitic chancre (Hard chancre) Donovanosis/ granuloma inguinale Chancroid (soft chancre) LGV
Incubation period 2-7 days

10-90 days 

Average: 21days

 1-12 weeks 1-14 days 3 days - 6 weeks
Causative agent HSV-2>HSV-1 Treponema pallidum Klebsiella granulomatis Hemophilus ducreyi

Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1,L2,L3
Clinical presentation

Cluster of vesicles on erythematous base.

Painful and pruritic lymphadenopathy

Single painless ulcer with a clean base and a firm raised border.

Painless lymphadenopathy

Painless papule or nodule erodes into beefy red granulomatous ulcer with rolled edges.

No lymphadenopathy, pseudobubos are seen

Painful ulcer (ducreyi makes you cry).

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy

Painless genital ulcer.

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy
Diagnosis  Tzanck preparation shows multinucleated giant cells, PCR Clinical diagnosis Donovan bodies on biopsy Clinical diagnosis Nucleic acid amplification tests
Treatment Acyclovir/famcyclovir or valacyclovir Penicillin/Ceftriaxone

Azithromycin/Doxycycline

 Azithromycin/ceftriaxone  Doxycycline

questions.text: Which of the following subtypes of HIV is most common in India?
questions.solution:
Subtype C of HIV is the most common in India. It causes more than 95% of HIV infections.  

Subtypes A and C are more readily transmitted by heterosexual contact than subtype B, which is mainly transmitted by homosexual contact and injections.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, productive cough, and weight loss. He gives a history of not having completed treatment for tuberculosis thrice in the past. Extensively drug-resistant TB is suspected. How is this entity defined?

choices.text: Resistance to INH + Amikacin + Ofloxacin + Ethambutol
Resistance to INH + Rifampicin + Ofloxacin + Linezolid

questions.solution:
XDR-TB (extensively drug-resistant TB) is defined as multi-drug resistant  TB (resistant to rifampicin and isoniazid) which is also resistant to one fluoroquinolone (eg. ofloxacin) AND resistant to atleast one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

It is usually seen in patients who have previously received treatment for TB and have either failed to complete treatment or relapsed.

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments
H mono-resistant/ poly-drug resistant TB regimen Lfx R E Z for 6 months

6 months long

Oral drugs only
BPaLM regime (New MDR regime by WHO) Bdq Pa Lzd Mfx for 6 months

6 months long
9- 11 months shorter oral bedaquiline regime (Shorter MDR)

Intensive Phase:

Lfx Bdq(6 months) Cfz Z Hh E Eto for 4-6 months

Continuation phase:

Lfx Cfz Z E for 5 months

9-11 months long totally

Injectables used in Intensive phase.
Longer MDR TB regimen Bdq(6 months or longer) Lfx Lzd Cfz Cs 

18-20 months long

Oral drugs only

This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

 

Criteria for patients to receive standard Drug Resistant TB regimen:

Standard Drug Resistant TB regimen Inclusion criteria Exclusion criteria
H mono-resistant/poly-drug resistant TB regimen Isoniazid resistant TB with rifampicin sensitive No specific criteria
BPaLM regimen (New MDR TB regimen by WHO)
  1. MDR/RR-TB or pre-XDR-TB ( MDR/RR-TB and resistance to fluoroquinolones). 
  2. Those with confirmed pulmonary TB and all forms of extrapulmonary TB (except for TB involving CNS, osteoarticular, and miliary TB).
  3. Patients >14 years of age.
 Pregnant and lactating women
9- 11 months shorter MDR TB regimen Patient with rifampicin resistant pulmonary or extra pulmonary TB Non drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • Pregnancy
  • Any extra pulmonary disease in PLHIV
  • Disseminated meningeal or central nervous system TB
  • Intolerance to any drug in the shorter MDR TB regimen
Drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • If DST/DRT result for FQ or SLI is resistant (XDR TB)
  • Presence of InhA mutation
  • Resistant to Z 
Longer MDR TB regimen Patients in whom shorter MDR TB regimen cannot be considered due to any reason None

Legend

FQ: Fluoroquinolone

SLI: Second Line Injectable

PLHIV: People Living with HIV

Lfx: Levofloxacin

Pa: Pretomanid

H: Isoniazid

Hh: High Dose Isoniazid

R: Rifampicin

E: Ethambutol

Z: Pyrazinamide

Mfx: Moxifloxacin

Km: Kanamycin

Am: Amikacin

Eto: Ethionamide

Cfz: Clofazimine

Bdq: Bedaquiline

Lzd: Linezolid

Cs: Cycloserine

questions.text: The quality of drinking water is considered to be satisfactory if the presumptive coliform count is _____.
questions.solution:
According to WHO guidelines, the quality of drinking water is considered to be satisfactory if the presumptive coliform count is 0/100 mL.

Presumptive coliform count

  • The basis of the presumptive coliform test is the inoculation of the water to be tested into tubes containing a suitable liquid medium, which are then incubated and examined after the appropriate period of time.
  • The test is called presumptive because the reaction observed in the tube may occasionally be due to the presence of some other organism or combination of organisms, and the presumption that the reaction is due to coliform organisms has to be confirmed.
  • The proportion of false-positive reactions obtained depends both on the bacterial flora of the water under examination and on the medium used.
  • Lactose broth, or MacConkey's broth, with bromocresol purple 25 as an indicator and a standardized concentration of bile salts incubated between 35°C–37°C for 48 hours, seems to be the most suitable media for presumptive tests.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a virulence factor for Neisseria gonorrhoea?
questions.solution:
M proteins are important virulence factors for Streptococcus pyogenes and not for Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

Virulence factors for gonococci:

  1. Outer Membrane Proteins (OMPs)
  2. IgA proteases
  3. Pili
  4. Lipo-oligosaccharide (LOS)
  5. Transferrin
  6. Lactoferrin-binding protein

questions.text: A patient has presented to the PHC with fever and chills. You order a rapid diagnostic test to detect HRP-2 antigen. Which of the following diseases is it used to diagnose?
questions.solution:
HRP-2 antigen detection is used in the diagnosis of malaria.

Malaria antigens detected by the rapid immunochromatographic test are:

  • pLDH - Positive in all Plasmodium species
  • HRP-2 - Positive for P. falciparum

The below image shows rapid diagnostic test (RDT) kit for malaria.

Related Pearl: Important serological tests for the diagnosis of parasitic infections

Serological tests are helpful for the detection and surveillance of many protozoal and helminthic infections.

These tests are basically of 2 types:

  • Tests for antigen detection
  • Tests for antibody detection

Antigen Detection:

Antigen

Parasite

Galactose lectin antigen

Entamoeba histolytica

Giardia-specific antigen 65

Giardia lamblia

WKK and rk39 antigen

Leishmania donovani

HRP-2 antigen

Plasmodium falciparum

Vivax-specific pLDH

Plasmodium vivax

200 KD Ag and OG4C3 antigen

Wuchereria bancrofti

 

Antibody detection:

  • Complement fixation test (CFT)
  • Indirect hemagglutination test (IHA)
  • Indirect immunofluorescent antibody test (IFA)
  • Rapid immunochromatography test
  • ELISA test

questions.text: Which of the following bacteria is a diphtheroid and is pyrazinamidase positive and urease positive?
questions.solution:
Corynebacterium hofmanni is a diphtheroid and is pyrazinamidase positive and urease positive.

  • Diphtheroids are corynebacteria, resembling Corynebacterium diphtheriae, occurring as normal commensals in the throat, skin, conjunctiva, and other areas.
  • The common diphtheroids include C. hofmanni and Cornybacterium xerosis.
  • Both C. hofmanni and C. xerosis are pyrazinamidase positive unlike C. diphtheriae.
  • C. hofmanni, also known as Corynebacterium pseudodiphtheriticum, is urease positive and non-fermentative.
  • C. xerosis is urease negative and ferments glucose.
  • Corynebacterium ulcerans is pyrazinamidase negative.

questions.text: A young child was brought to the ER with a history of loose stools. On examination, she is tachycardic, appears lethargic and skin goes back slowly after the skin pinch test. She was admitted and started on IV fluids and input-output charting was done. The given image shows stool output from the patient. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of the toxin responsible for the same?

choices.text: Toxin causes Increased guanyl cyclase activity
The toxin causes continued activation of adenylate cyclase

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of dehydration, profuse diarrhea, and rice water stools is suggestive of cholera. Cholera toxin causes continued activation of adenylate cyclase. 

 Mechanism of action of cholera toxin:

  • The cholera toxin molecule consists of 1 A and 5 B subunits. The B (binding) units attach to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells. The A (active) subunit, on being transported into the enterocyte, dissociates into A1 and A2. A2 fragment only links biologically active A1 to the B subunit.
  • A1 causes prolonged activation of cellular adenylate cyclase and accumulation of cAMP, leading to outpouring into the small intestinal lumen, of large quantities of water and electrolytes and the consequent watery diarrhea, that is isotonic with plasma but contains much more of potassium and bicarbonate.
  • The toxin also inhibits the intestinal absorption of sodium and chloride.
  • All clinical manifestations and complications in cholera result from the massive water and electrolyte depletion thus caused.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: A veterinarian is administered three doses of the human diploid cell anti-rabies vaccine as pre-exposure prophylaxis. Which of the following is false about the viral strain present in the vaccine?

choices.text: The incubation period is short and fixed
It is produced by serial passage through rabbit brains
It can multiply in neural tissue

questions.solution:
The human diploid cell anti-rabies vaccine consists of the fixed rabies virus grown on human diploid cells. The fixed virus does not produce Negri bodies.  

The fixed virus is produced by serial passage of the street rabies virus through rabbit brains. It is neurotropic and multiples in neural tissues. When inoculated intracerebrally, it produces fatal encephalitis. The incubation period for this is short and fixed, and the course of encephalitis is predictable. Negri bodies cannot be demonstrated in the brains of animals inoculated with the fixed virus. This virus is used for anti-rabies vaccine production.

questions.text: All of the following statements about Helicobacter pylori are true except that

choices.text: Gastric fundus is the most common site of colonization
Helicobacter pylori infection is associated with increased risk of gastric adenocarcinoma
The triple regimen for the treatment of H.pylori includes omeprazole, clarithromycin, and metronidazole
The urea breath test, the stool antigen test, and biopsy-based tests can all be used to assess the success of treatment

questions.solution:
The most common site of colonization of H. pylori in the stomach is the gastric antrum although any part of the stomach can be involved.

  • H. pylori infection increases the risk of gastric malignancies such as gastric adenocarcinoma and MALTomas (i.e., mucous-associated lymphoid tisse lymphomas).
  • MALTomas are found to regress with the elimination of H. pylori.
  • The triple regimen for the treatment of H. pylori includes omeprazole, clarithromycin, and metronidazole (see table below)
  • The urea breath test, the stool antigen test, and biopsy-based tests can all be used to assess the success of treatment.
  • Serology cannot be used for follow-up after treatment as the fall in H.pylori specific antibody titer is too slow to be of practical use.

Management of H. pylori infection

Regimen Drug 1 Drug 2 Drug 3 Drug 4

Regimen 1: OCM

(14 days)

 Omeprazole(20 mg bid) Clarithromycin(500 mg bid)

Metronidazole (500 mg bid)

 --

Regimen 2: OCA (14 days)

Omeprazole (20 mg bid)

Clarithromycin (500 mg bid)

Amoxicillin (1 g bid)

 --

Regimen 3: OBTM (14 days)

Omeprazole (20 mg bid)

Bismuth subsalicylate (2 tabs

qid)

  

Tetracycline HCl (500 mg qid)

  

Metronidazole (500 mg tid)

Regimen 4: concomitant

(14 days)

Omeprazole (20 mg bid)

Amoxicillin (1 g bid)

Clarithromycin (500 mg bid)

Tinidazole (500 mg bid)

Regimen 5: OAL (10 days)

Omeprazole (20 mg bid)

Amoxicillin (1 g bid)

Levofloxacin (500 mg bid)

 --

The recommended first-line regimens for most of the world are shown in bold type.

Regimen 1 & 2 should be used only for populations in which the prevalence of clarithromycin resistant strains is known to be <20%.

questions.text: A young man presents to the ER with complaints of sudden onset nausea, vomiting, and four episodes of passing loose stools. He gives a history of having food from a nearby restaurant three hours ago. Which of the following organisms is most likely implicated here?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical history, the patient is most likely suffering from gastroenteritis caused by Staphylococcus aureus. 

Staphylococcus causes nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea 2-6 hrs after the consumption of contaminated food. Other organisms causing food poisoning within the same time period of 2-6 hrs are the emetic strains of Bacillus cereus.

Gastroeneteritis is caused by enterotoxin produced by S. aureus. It is a preformed toxin that is relatively heat stable while most of the other exotoxins are heat-labile. It stimulates the vagus nerve and vomiting centre of the brain and also stimulates intestinal peristaltic activity. Eight antigenic types of enterotoxin are currently known of which is Type  A toxin is responsible for most cases.

Related Pearl: Food Poisoning

Organism Symptoms Common food source
1–6 hrs incubation period  
Staphylococcus aureus Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea Ham, poultry, potato, cream pastries, mayonnaise
Bacillus cereus Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea Fried rice
8–16 hrs incubation period  
Clostridium perfringes Abdominal cramps, diarrhea Beef, poultry, legume, gravies
Bacillus cereus Abdominal cramps, diarrhea Meat, vegetables, dried beans, cereals
>16 hrs incubation period  
Vibrio cholerae Watery diarrhea Shellfish, water
Salmonella species Inflammatory diarrhea Beef, poultry, eggs
Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli Watery diarrhea Salads, cheese, meats
Enterohemorrhagic E. coli Bloody diarrhea Raw milk, raw vegetables, apple juice
Campylobacter jejuni Inflammatory diarrhea Poultry, raw milk
Shigella species Dysentery Potato, egg salad, lettuce
Vibrio parahaemolyticus Dysentery Molluscs, crustaceans

questions.text: A 35-year-old bisexual man goes to an ICTC centre for counselling about HIV. Which of the following is false about HIV transmission?

choices.text: Male-to-female HIV transmission has more risk of causing infection than female-to-male transmission
The risk of acquiring HIV with unprotected receptive anal intercourse is lower than that with penile-vaginal intercourse
The quantity of HIV-1 in plasma is a primary determinant of the risk of HIV-1 transmission
Male circumcision is associated with a lower risk of HIV acquisition for heterosexual men

questions.solution:
The risk of HIV acquisition associated with unprotected receptive anal intercourse is relatively higher than that seen in penile-vaginal intercourse. This is because the rectal mucosal membrane is thin and fragile and anal intercourse is associated with microtrauma (rectal tears). 

The differences in transmission rates between men and women are because the vagina and cervix are exposed to semen for a longer duration, increasing the risk of transmission. However, the penis and urethral orifice are exposed relatively briefly to infected vaginal fluid, lowering the risk.

questions.text: Which of the following is the first sign of generalized tetanus?
questions.solution:
The first sign of generalized tetanus is increased tone of the masseter muscle, which results in trismus or lock-jaw.

Tetanus:

  • Route of entry of organism- injury, unhygienic surgery, abortion/delivery, otitis media
  • The incubation period is 6-10 days.
  • First clinical sign- increased masseter tone (trismus/lock-jaw) followed by descending tetanus
  • Deep tendon reflex is exaggerated.
  • In neonates, difficulty in feeding is the usual presentation.
  • Diagnosis is always clinical, microscopy is unreliable.
  • Treatment includes cleaning the entry wound first in order to remove anaerobic foci of infection and prevent further toxin production. Metronidazole is preferred for antibiotic therapy. Antitoxin should be given early in an attempt to deactivate any circulating tetanus toxin. Spasms are controlled by heavy sedation with benzodiazepines. Symptomatic treatment is given for respiratory and cardiovascular derangements.

questions.text: Not true about botulinum toxin

choices.text: Used for the treatment of Blepharospasm, static and dynamic wrinkles
Permanantly decreases acetylcholine in neuromuscular junction

questions.solution:
Botulinum toxin acts by blocking the production and release of acetylcholine at the synapses and neuromuscular junction. Hence, this is an incorrect statement.

  • Site of action: Pre-synaptic neuromuscular junctions, postganglionic parasympathetic nerve endings, and peripheral ganglia.
  • It is used in the treatment of neuromuscular disorder like strabismus, blepharospasm, wrinkle, myoclonus (since botulism toxin produces flaccid paralysis).
  • The action is short lasting and recovery occurs in 2-4 months once the new terminal axon sprouts form and restore transmission.
  • Blocking of acetylcholine release from nerve terminal is permanent and recovery occurs only by sprouting of new nerve
    terminals.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl is brought with complaints of sensitivity to light and profuse lacrimation. On inspection, the given finding is seen on her upper tarsal conjunctiva. What type of hypersensitivity reaction is this?
questions.solution:
Spring catarrh or vernal keratoconjunctivitis is a type I hypersensitivity reaction.

It is a bilateral, seasonally recurrent, chronic conjunctivitis due to type I hypersensitivity allergic reaction to an external antigen. The antigen reacts with IgE, this stimulates mast cell degranulation leading to the release of histamine and other mediators of the allergic response.

Spring catarrh is one of the several forms of allergic conjunctivitis.

questions.text: Pertussis or whooping cough is also commonly known as __________.
questions.solution:
Pertussis is commonly known as 100-Day cough.

The word pertussis means violent cough, which describes the most consistent feature of the illness.

The inspiratory sound "whoop" made at the end of an episode of paroxysmal coughing, gives it the common name for the illness, whooping cough.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding transfer factor?

choices.text: The transferred CMI is local at injection site and not systemic
It has been used in the treatment of Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome
The immunity offered by it is referred to as adoptive immunity

questions.solution:
The transferred cell mediated immunity is not local at the injected site. It is systemic.

The cell-mediated immunity (CMI) can be transferred in human beings by the injection of extracts from leucocytes. This extract is known as transfer factor(TF).

The immunity transferred as a result of injection of the Transfer factor is referred to as Adoptive immunity.

The Cell Mediated Immunity can be transferred only to those antigens to which the donor is sensitive.

TF is dialysable, low molecular weight substance.

Applications of Transfer factor:

  • To restore immune capacity in patients with T-cell deficiency (Wiskott – Aldrich syndrome)
  • Treatment of disseminated infections associated with deficient cell mediated immunity such as Lepromatous leprosy, Tuberculosis Mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • Treatment of Malignant melanoma
  • In treatment of autoimmune diseases such as Systemic lupus erythematosus, Rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy presents with meningococcal meningitis. He has a history of recurrent bacterial chest and ear infections. Family history reveals that he has a male cousin (maternal side) who died in infancy from infection. The physician suspects X-linked agammaglobulinemia. Which of the following is false regarding his condition?

choices.text: It is caused by a mutation of the BTK gene
Both humoral and cell mediated immunity are affected
All classes of immunoglobulin levels are reduced
Lymph node biopsy shows depletion of follicles

questions.solution:
X-linked or Bruton's agammaglobulinemia is primarily a disease of humoral immunity. Cell-mediated immunity is not affected.

It is an inherited immunodeficiency disease caused by mutations in the gene coding for Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK). B cells do not differentiate and mature. They are arrested in the pre-B cell stage.

There are extremely low IgG levels (below 100 mg/dL) and an absence of other immunoglobulin classes. The tonsils and lymph nodes are usually atrophic. Lymph node biopsy reveals depletion of cells of B cell-dependent areas (follicles). Babies born with this disorder have virtually no peripheral B cells (<1%) and suffer from recurrent bacterial infections.

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text: Which of the following is false about viral hepatitis?

choices.text: Anti LKM-3 antibody is associated with hepatitis B infection
Anti-LKM1 antibodies are associated with hepatitis C infection
IgM anti-HAV antibody appears during the late incubation period
Enterically transmitted non-A, non-B hepatitis is caused by hepatitis E virus

questions.solution:
The anti-LKM-3 antibody is associated with hepatitis D infection, not hepatitis B.

Anti–liver-kidney microsomal antibodies (anti-LKM) are many of several autoantibodies that are detected in the serum of patients with different types of acute or chronic liver disease. These antibodies are targeted against antigens of the cytochrome P450 system.

They are also associated with chronic hepatitis C and autoimmune hepatitis.

Option C: IgM anti-HAV antibody indicates current/recent infection. It appears during the late incubation period, peaks in 2-3 weeks, and disappears after 3-4 months. IgG denotes remote infection or immunity. It appears around the same time, peaks at 3-4 months, and persists for a long time. 

Option D: Hepatitis E infection was previously known as an epidemic or enterically transmitted non-A, non-B hepatitis. It is transmitted by feco-oral route. 

Related Pearl: Antibodies in Hepatitis

 

Antibodies Seen in

ANA, ASMA, pANCA, anti-SLA/LP, AMA

Autoimmune hepatitis Type 1
Anti-liver cytosol 1

Autoimmune hepatitis Type 2
Anti-LKM 1

Autoimmune hepatitis Type 2 

Chronic hepatitis C
Anti-LKM 2 Drug-induced hepatitis
Anti-LKM 3

Chronic hepatitis D
  • ANA: Anti-nuclear antibodies (most common antibody in autoimmune hepatitis)
  • LKM: Liver–kidney microsomes
  • SLA/LP: Soluble liver antigen/liver-pancreas
  • ASMA: Anti-smooth muscle actin
  • pANCA: Perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies
  • AMA: Antimitochondrial antibodies

questions.text: Which of the following does not play a role in the virulence of Vibrio cholerae?
questions.solution:
Vibrio cholerae possesses lipopolysaccharide (LPS) O antigen but it plays no role in the pathogenesis of cholera. It is responsible for the immunity induced by killed vaccines.

Factors involved in virulence of Vibrio cholerae:  

  • In the small intestine, vibrios can cross the protective layer of mucus and reach the epithelial cells by using mucinase and other proteolytic enzymes.
  • Toxin co-regulated pilus(TCP), is essential for the adhesion to the epithelial surface and colonization of the bacteria in small intestine.
  • Cholera toxin (also known as choleragen and cholera enterotoxin) causes watery diarrhea through cAMP-mediated pathway.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: In a splenectomized patient, there is an increased risk of infection by all capsulated organisms. Which of the following is least likely to cause an infection in such patients?
questions.solution:
In splenectomized patients, there is an increased risk of infection by capsulated organisms such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Klebsiella pneumoniae. Staphylococcus aureus does not have a capsule and so poses no increased risk to these individuals.

The phagocytosis of capsulated organisms is prevented by their capsule. Thus, the body's main defence against these organisms is the spleen.

Certain components called opsonins attach to these capsulated organisms, and then they are delivered to the spleen, where their uptake is facilitated by receptors present on the surface of splenic phagocytes. After splenectomy, this defence mechanism is lost leaving patients susceptible to infection from these bacteria.

Related Pearl: Overwhelming Post-splenectomy Infection (OPSI)

It is the most common fatal infection following splenectomy. 

Certain components called opsonins attach to the encapsulated organisms, and then they are delivered to the spleen, where their uptake is facilitated by receptors present on the surface of splenic phagocytes. After splenectomy, this defence mechanism is lost leaving patients susceptible to infection from these bacteria.

Most common within 2-3 years following splenectomy. 

Causative agents: Usually capsulated organisms like

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (Most common)
  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Streptococcus species
  • Salmonella species
  • Capnocytophaga canimorsus, implicated in OPSI as a result of dog bites

Clinical features

  • Prodromal features like fever, chills, sore throat, malaise, diarrhea, and vomiting
  • Rapid progression to hypotension, disseminated intravascular coagula­tion, respiratory distress, coma, and death within hours of presen­tation
  • High-grade bacteremia with no identifiable foci of infection
  • Poor response to antibiotics

If an elective splenectomy is planned, prophylactic vaccinations against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years), and H. influenzae type B (Hib) must be given atleast 2 weeks before the elective surgery.

In case of an emergency splenectomy, patients should be vaccinated as soon as possible after recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about tuberculin test?

choices.text: TB pericarditis patient may have positive test
Miliary TB may come out as negative test
Tuberculin test is the only way to diagnose pulmonary TB if sputum smear and microscopy is negative

questions.solution:
Tuberculin may be false negative in conditions such as early TB, late or miliary TB, patients with low CMI, sarcoidosis or following measles.

Patients with sarcoidosis may show anergy (absence of the normal immune response to a particular antigen or allergen).

Even in extrapumlonary TB like TB pericarditis, tuberculin test is positive unless the patient is immunocompromised.

Interpretation of result of tuberculin test:

  • Adults: Positive test only confirms past infection but does not indicate the presence of the active stage of the disease. It is only used as epidemiological marker.
  • Children: Indicates active infection and used as a diagnostic marker.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most potent stimulator of naive T-cells?
questions.solution:
Mature dendritic cells are the most potent stimulator of naive T cells.

Naive CD4+ T cells are activated when they come in contact with two ligands - MHC class II and a costimulary membrane protein (eg: CD28). Both of these are present in antigen-presenting cells, the most potent of which is the mature dendritic cell. Other professional antigen-presenting cells include macrophages and B lymphocytes (option C).

Other options:

Option B: Follicular dendritic cells are functionally different from dendritic cells. They are not antigen-presenting-cells and do not activate naive T cells.

Option D: NK cells do not stimulate naive T cells.

questions.text: A young lady complains of recurrent rhinitis, nasal discharge and bilateral nasal blockage for two years.  She has a history of allergic rhinitis. On rhinoscopy, multiple ethmoidal polyps with mucosal thickening and impacted secretions are seen in both the nasal cavities. A tissue biopsy is taken and sent for culture, which on microscopic examination shows the following appearance. What is the most probable organism implicated here?
questions.solution:
Recurrent rhinitis, chronic nasal discharge, bilateral nasal blockage, multiple ethmoidal polyps and the microscopic appearance of conical vesicles with conidia over two-thirds of the vesicle is suggestive of allergic fungal rhinosinusitis caused by Aspergillus fumigatus.

Aspergillus spp. can lead to the following types of sinusitis:

  1. Acute invasive sinusitis: It affects immunocompromised patients. They present with fever, nasal or facial discomfort, blocked nose and bloody nasal discharge. Pale, dusky or necrotic tissue will be present within the sinuses.
  2. Chronic aspergillus sinusitis:
    • Fungal ball of sinus: The maxillary sinus, most commonly, is filled with an aspergillus ball. No tissue invasion is present.
    • Chronic invasive sinusitis: There is slow destruction of the ethmoid and sphenoid sinuses with bone destruction and localised spread. Patients present with chronic nasal discharge and blockage, loss of the sense of smell and persistent headache. Involvement of the orbit results in proptosis and blindness.
    • Chronic granulomatous sinusitis: Patients present with facial swelling and unilateral proptosis. Biopsied tissue shows granulomatous (not necrotic) reaction.
  3. Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis: Patients present with chronic sinusitis and nasal polyps. On microscopy, eosinophilia and Charcot-Leyden crystals can be seen.

On microscopic examination of the sinus or polyp tissue, hyaline, septate, acute branching hyphae of Aspergillus spp. can be seen. The various species can be differentiated based on the appearance of the conidiophores. In Aspergillus fumigatus, the vesicle is conical. Phialides are arranged in a single row. Conidia arise from the upper two-thirds of the vesicle and are hyaline.

Option B: Aspergillus flavus has a globular vesicle. Phialides are arranged in one or two rows. Conidia arise from the entire vesicle and are hyaline.

Option C: Aspergillus niger has a globular-shaped vesicle. Phialides are in two rows. Conidia arise from the entire vesicle and are black.

Option D: Penicillium chrysogenum has septate hyphae with branched conidiophores bearing chains of spores (brush or broom appearance).

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presented to the ER with fever, splenomegaly, and a rash as shown in the image below. After admission, he developed intestinal perforation  and an exploratory laparotomy revealed several longitudinal ulcers in the small bowel. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Rose spots. The combination of this with fever, splenomegaly, presence of longitudinal ulcers in the intestine and intestinal perforation is suggestive of enteric fever.

The term enteric fever includes typhoid fever caused by Salmonella typhi and paratyphoid fever caused by Salmonella paratyphi A, B and C.

Enteric fever presents with step ladder pyrexia. The fever is accompanied by relative bradycardia which is known as the Faget sign. Hepatosplenomegaly is a common finding on examination. Rose spots that fade on pressure appear on the skin during the second or third week. 

Since bile is a good culture medium for the bacilli, they multiply abundantly in the gallbladder and are discharged continuously into the intestine. In the intestine, it causes inflammation and necrosis leaving behind the characteristic typhoid ulcers which are oriented along the axis of the intestine (longitudinal ulcers). Ulceration of the bowel leads to two major complications- intestinal perforation and hemorrhage.

Option B: In intestinal tuberculosis, ulcers are perpendicular to the axis of the intestine (transverse ulcers).

Option C: Flask shaped ulcers are characteristic of amoebiasis.

Option D: Hemorrhagic colitis is caused by Shigella dysenteriae and some strains of E. coli. It is characterised by bloody diarrhea with tenesmus.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presented with a runny nose and bullous lesions on the skin and legs. Her X-ray (given below) showed features suggestive of periostitis. Which of the following is the initial investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
The newborn baby has characteristic signs and symptoms of congenital syphilis. Periostitis is a hallmark of skeletal manifestation. VDRL or RPR is the initial investigation of choice in congenital syphilis.

The earliest manifestations of congenital syphilis include rhinitis, or “snuffles”; mucocutaneous lesions, bone changes, including periostitis detectable by x-ray examination of long bones; hepatosplenomegaly,  lymphadenopathy, anemia, jaundice, thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis. They can also have dental deformities such as Hutchinson's teeth which describes notches in teeth and mulberry molars. 

All neonates born to mothers who have reactive nontreponemal and treponemal test results should be evaluated with a quantitative nontreponemal serologic test (RPR or VDRL) performed on the neonate’s serum because umbilical cord blood can become contaminated with maternal blood and yield a false-positive result.

FTA-ABS or TPHA is used for confirmation of syphilis in a patient with reactive RPR or VDRL test.
T. pallidum cannot be detected by culture.

questions.text: Unilateral sex-linked histoincompatibility is known as _____
questions.solution:
Eichwald–Silmser effect is known as unilateral sex-linked histoincompatibility.

  • While transplants between siblings are successful, an exception is seen when the donor is a male and the recipient a female.
  • Such grafts are rejected as the grafted male tissue (XY) will have antigens determined by the Y chromosome which will be absent in the female (XX) recipient.
  • Grafts from the female to the male will succeed.
  • This unilateral sex linked histoincompatibility is known as the Eichwald-Silmser effect.

questions.text: An unresponsive middle-aged man with fever and petechial rashes was rushed into the ER. You successfully resuscitate him. Abdominal ultrasound shows bilateral adrenal hemorrhage. Which of the following statements is false regarding his condition?

choices.text: Patients who recover may suffer from sloughing of the skin
The implicated organism can be isolated from the petechial rashes
The causative organism is Neisseria gonorrheae
Hypoplastic spleen is a risk factor for this condition

questions.solution:
The above scenario depicts Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome which is a complication seen in infection with meningococci. Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome is also known as hemorrhagic adrenalitis or fulminant meningococcemia and is characterized by bilateral adrenal gland hemorrhage. 

Though Waterhouse-Freiderichsen syndrome is most often associated with meningococcal septicemia, it may complicate sepsis caused by other organisms like certain streptococcal species also. Hypoplastic spleen may also be associated with this condition and the implicated organism can be isolated from the petechial rashes.

Complications : 

  • Shock, extensive hemorrhage within the skin
  • May fall into a coma
  • Death, usually after a few hours, due to adrenal insufficiency
  • Patients who recover may suffer from extensive sloughing of the skin and loss of digits due to gangrene.

Fulminant meningococcemia is a medical emergency and needs to be treated with adequate antibiotics as fast as possible. Ceftriaxone is an antibiotic commonly used nowadays.

questions.text: Which of the following is the drug of choice for the treatment of hemophilus meningitis?
questions.solution:
3rd-generation cephalosporins like cefotaxime or ceftazidime are the drugs of choice for the treatment of hemophilus meningitis. 

Ampicillin and cotrimoxazole were popular for respiratory infections, but as plasmid-borne resistance to these drugs is now common, they are not recommended anymore. Amoxicillin-clavulanate can still be given and is is more effective than cotrimoxazole or ampicillin.

questions.text: Which of the following syndromes corresponds to a failure of neutrophils to generate an immune response and lab values indicate elevated IgE levels?
questions.solution:
Job’s Syndrome corresponds to a failure of neutrophils to generate an immune response and lab values indicate elevated IgE levels.

Hyperimmunoglobulinemia E syndrome - its autosomal dominant form is called Job's syndrome or Buckley syndrome.

  • It is a disorder of phagocytosis associated with elevated IgE levels.
  • This is characterized by multiple large staphylococcal ‘cold’ abscesses, which occur repeatedly on the skin containing large quantities of pus.
  • Atopic eczema, chronic nasal discharge, and otitis media are common features.

questions.text: What is the average incubation period for Hepatitis A virus?
questions.solution:
The average incubation period of the Hepatitis A virus (HAV) is around 30 days. It ranges from 15-50 days. The clinical disease has a prodromal stage and an icteric stage.

Related Pearl: The Hepatitis Viruses

  HAV HBV HCV HDV HEV
Specific name Hepatovirus A Hepatitis B virus Hepacivirus C Hepatitis D virus Orthohepevirus A
Family Picornaviridae Hepadnaviridae Flaviviridae Kolmioviridae (genus deltavirus) Hepeviridae
Envelope Non enveloped Enveloped Enveloped Envelope from HBV Quasi-enveloped
Nuclear material ssRNA Partially dsDNA ssRNA Circular defective ssRNA ssRNA
Antigens HAV Ag HBsAg, HBcAg, HBeAg, HBxAg HCV Ag HBsAg, HDAg HEV Ag
Antibodies Anti-HAV Ab Anti-HBs Ab, Anti-HBc Ab, Anti-HBe Ab Anti-HCV Ab Anti-HBs Ab, Anti-HDV Ab Anti-HEV Ab
Auto-antibodies     Anti-LKM 1 Anti-LKM 3  
Routes of transmission Feco-oral, parenteral, sexual Perinatal, parenteral, sexual, percutaneous, direct mucosal contact Parenteral, perinatal, percutaneous, sexual Parenteral, sexual Feco-oral, zoonotic, vertical
Incubation period 30 days 60 days 50 days 60 days 40 days
Chances of fulminant hepatic failure 0.1% 0.1 to 1% 0.1% 5% in coinfections and 20% in superinfections 1-2% in adults and up to 25% in pregnant women
Extrahepatic manifestations Rash, arthralgia Polyarteritis nodosa and membranous nephropathy Essential mixed cryoglobulinemia, MPGN, Metabolic syndrome       - GBS, Bell’s palsy, pancreatitis,  and glomerulonephritis
Resolution of acute infection 2 months 6 months 6 months 6 months 3 months
Progression to chronic infection No 5-10% >80%

10% of co-infections,

90–100% of superinfections

Only in immuno-compromised
HCC No May develop in chronic infections May develop in chronic infections May develop in chronic infections May develop in chronic infections
Vaccine Available Available          - HBV vaccine           -
Therapy None Entecavir, tenofovir, pegIFN-𝛂 Velpatasvir, sofosbuvir, ribavirin PegIFN-𝛂 None

Related Pearl: Diseases with usual incubation period

Disease Incubation period(days)
Dengue 5-8
Typhoid 10-14
Herpes simplex 5-8
Enterovirus disease 6-12
Poliomyelitis 5-20
Measles 9-12
Smallpox 12-14
Chickenpox 13-17
Mumps 16-20
Rubella 17-20
Mononucleosis 30-50
Hepatitis A 15-40
Hepatitis B & C 50-150

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about T cell dependent antigens?

choices.text: Their response doesn't show immunological memory
They activate only mature B cells

questions.solution:
T cell-dependent antigens activate only mature B cells.

Depending on their ability to induce the formation of antibodies, antigens are classified as T-cell dependent and T-cell independent antigens. 

T cell-dependent antigens (TD) T cell-independent antigens (TI)
Require helper T cell participation for the production of immune response Directly stimulate antibody production by B cells
Structurally complex Structurally simple
Activate only mature B cells monoclonally Activate both mature and immature B cells polyclonally
B cells undergo affinity maturation and class switch over B cells do not undergo affinity maturation and class switch over

All classes of antibodies are activated

 Antibody response is restricted to IgM and IgG3
Rapidly metabolized Slowly metabolized
Immunological memory present No immunological memory

questions.text: The capsid of a virus is best represented by which of the following marked structures?
questions.solution:
In the given image of a virus, the capsid is best represented by structure 3.

Viruses are the smallest infectious agents and contain only one kind of nucleic acid (RNA or DNA) as their genome. The infectious extracellular unit is termed a virion. The parts of a virus include the:

  1. Nucleocapsid: The protein coat (capsid) and its enclosed nucleic acid
  2. Tegument: The proteinaceous structure present between the envelope and capsid.
  3. Envelope: The lipid-containing membrane that surrounds some virus particles. It is acquired during viral maturation by a budding process through a host cell membrane.
  4. Peplomers: Virus-encoded glycoproteins present on the outer surface of the envelope as projections.

Viruses do not have a cellular organization. They lack enzymes necessary for protein and nucleic acid synthesis and are hence obligate intracellular parasites. They are filterable, cannot be grown on artificial media and are unaffected by antibiotics.

Note: Martinus Beijerinck proposed the theory of contagium vivum fluidum (living infectious fluid) while studying the cause of mosaic disease of tobacco plant. He is known as the father of virology.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presented to you with fever, malaise, and weight loss. On examination, you notice the finding shown in the image. In which of the following conditions is this seen?
questions.solution:
The given image shows posterior cervical lymphadenopathy which is called Winterbottom’s sign. It is seen in West African sleeping sickness.

It is seen in stage I of West African sleeping sickness caused by Trypanosoma brucei gambiense.

The table below shows diseases caused by various Trypanosoma species.

Protozoa

Disease

Trypanosoma brucei gambiense

West African sleeping sickness

Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense

East African sleeping sickness

Trypanosoma cruzi

Chagas’ disease/South American trypanosomiasis

questions.text: Which of the following immunoglobulins crosses placenta?
questions.solution:
IgG is the only maternal immunoglobulin that is normally transported across the placenta and provides natural passive immunity in the newborn.

  • Maximum placental transfer – IgG1
  • Minimum placental transfer – IgG2

questions.text: A  farmer from a tribal area is referred from his PHC with complaints of chest pain and hemoptysis. A CT chest was done and the finding is given in the image. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given CT scan shows water lily sign, which is seen in the hydatid disease of the lung. It is caused by Echinococcus granulosus.

The water-lily sign occurs due to detachment of the endocyst membrane from the cyst wall giving the apparance of floating membranes within the pericyst. This mimics the appearance of a water lily.

It is classically visualised on plain radiographs (mainly chest X-ray) when the collapsed membranes are calcified but may be seen on ultrasound, CT, or MRI.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding drug resistance?

choices.text: In mutational drug resistance one drug resistance is seen at a time
Virulence is decreased in transferable resistance
Drug combinations can prevent Mutational drug resistance
High degree of resistance is seen in transferable drug resistance

questions.solution:
• Virulence is not decreased in transferable drug resistance.
  • Transferable drug resistance is widely seen in various pathogenic and commensal bacteria of humans.
  • The transfer can be effected readily in vitro, but in the normal gut, it is inhibited by factors such as Bile salts, anaerobic conditions, and alkaline pH.

Related Pearl: Comparison of Mutational and Transferable Drug Resistance

Mutational drug resistance

Transferable drug resistance

One drug resistance at a time

Multiple drug resistance

Low degree resistance

High degree resistance

Can be overcome by high drug dose

High dose ineffective

Drug combinations can prevent

Drug combinations cannot prevent

Resistance does not spread

Spreads to same or different species

Mutants may be defective

Not defective

Virulence may be low

Virulence not decreased

questions.text: The virus with the smallest genome among the given options is _____.
questions.solution:
Hepatitis B virus has the smallest genome among the given options.

Largest genomic size- Poxvirus 

Smallest genomic size- Hepatitis D followed by Hepatits B

questions.text: Which of the following bacteria is associated with the causation of colorectal carcinoma, rectal polyp, endocarditis and septicaemia and is pyrrolidinyl arylamidase test negative?
questions.solution:
Streptococcus gallolyticus is associated with the causation of colorectal CA, rectal polyp, endocarditis, and septicemia and is pyrrolidinyl arylamidase test (PYR test) negative.

Streptococcus gallolyticus, formerly called Streptococcus bovis, is a non-enterococcal Group D streptococci. It is bile insoluble, esculin hydrolysis positive, PYR negative and shows no growth in 6.5% NaCl.

questions.text: A man presents with fever, chills and abdominal pain for 1 week. He underwent valve replacement for symptomatic aortic valve stenosis 4 months ago. On auscultation, an early diastolic murmur is noted along the lower left sternal margin which increases in intensity during the Valsalva maneuver. Which of the following statements is true about the most common organism causing this condition?
questions.solution:
Fever and chills with aortic regurgitation (an early diastolic murmur along the left sternal margin increasing in intensity during the Valsalva manoeuvre) in a patient with a prosthetic valve suggest a diagnosis of prosthetic valve left-sided infective endocarditis. The most common organism causing it within 12 months of surgery is coagulase-negative Staphylococci (CoNS). Its cell wall contains teichoic acid. 

Infective endocarditis is the microbial infection of heart valves or endocardium, leading to the formation of vegetations (thrombotic debris and microbial organisms). Patients present with fever, chills and heart murmurs. Non-cardiac manifestations like subungual hemorrhage, Osler's nodes and arteria emboli may be seen. The most common organism causing IE overall is Staphylococcus aureus. The most common organism causing prosthetic valve endocarditis within 12 months of surgery is coagulase-negative Staphylococci, like Staphylococcus epidermidis. 

Staphylococcus epidermidis is a Gram-positive coccus arranged in clusters. It is coagulase-negative (option B) and is resistant to lysostaphin (option D). It is non-hemolytic (option C). It is a part of normal flora of the human body.

The following image shows a graphical illustration of vegetations seen in infective endocarditis.

Related Pearl: Microbiology of Infective Endocarditis

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic patient presented with complaints of discoloration of his toenail for the past 4 months as shown in the image below. Which pathogen most commonly causes this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of onychomycosis and the pathogen most commonly associated with this condition is Trichophyton rubrum. Diabetes increases the risk of onychomycosis.

Onychomycosis refers to nail infections caused by fungi. It can be due to dermatophytes, non-dermatophytic moulds, and candida. Tinea unguium refers to nail infections caused by dermatophytes. This condition may affect toenails or fingernails, but toenail infections are particularly common. 

The following photomicrograph of the nail segment in KOH shows T. rubrum fungal hyphae invading nail cells.

The following image is of a lactophenol cotton blue(LPCB) mount showing pyriform shaped microconidia on the hyphae of T. rubrum.

Treatment for onychomycosis is with oral terbinafine or azoles for 6 weeks to 3 months, depending on the depth of infection and whether the infection is on the hand or toe nail.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false?

choices.text: Muramic acid is present in prokaryotes
Mitotic division is present in eukaryotes
Multiple linear chromosomes present in eukaryotes

questions.solution:
80S ribosome is present in eukaryotes, while 70S ribosome is present in prokaryotes.

80S ribosome has subunits 60S and 40S, while 70S has subunits 50S and 30S.
